VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during the licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during
this licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001252 with CAP approval date of 06/28/2024 was
a result of two unwarranted restraints and incident reports for the restraints not
entered on time. The facility provided training to staff regarding what behaviors
warrant intervention by physical restraint and created an electronic health record
to be reviewed during residential check in/check out to ensure all incident reports
for restraints have been properly documented. The facility complied with the CAP
action steps and DCWL closed the CAP after six months of monitoring compliance
with no concerns.
Special Investigation 2024SIC0001364 with CAP approval date of 6/28/2024 was
a result of the facility failing to have a behavior management policy. The facility
added and trained staff on Behavior Management and Youth Code of Conduct
Policies. The facility complied with the CAP action steps and DCWL closed the
CAP after six months of monitoring compliance with no concerns.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the annual financial
audit report.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator reported newer staff are working in the house and they are
working on getting the right kind of staff to work with the youth. The Chief
Administrator stated the youth are getting what they need and their needs are being
met. It was reported corrective action plans, CAPs, have been more for an
individual staff versus an agency as a whole. The CAPs have been successfully
implemented.
3

Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported feeling supported by co-workers, their supervisor and administration.
One staff member stated the weekly house meetings are helpful because as a
team they discuss the top youth in the house who have been struggling and
discuss strategies to better help those youth. Staff reported the youth are getting
what they need to move through the program and be successful.
Youth reported in interviews the facility is a "good place to be at, people care about
you, and staff stop fights to keep me safe." One youth stated it was the best place
he has been at because of all the outings. All of the youth interviewed expressed
understanding of the program and expectations.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on February 26, 2025. There were no issues
or safety concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
